description: This protocol will introduce a workflow for quality control and pre-processing of metagenomic sequence reads using FastQC for visualization and FastX Toolkit for editing the fastq files.

components.data: Load FastQC:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Load FastQC:

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 1 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Preprocessing
source_data.annotation: The FastQC tools will provide visualization for the quality of the sequence reads for each of your samples.
source_data.thread_text: The FastQC tools will provide visualization for the quality of the sequence reads for each of your samples.
source_data.body: The FastQC tools will provide visualization for the quality of the sequence reads for each of your samples.

source_data.name: $ module load fastqc
source_data.description: This command can be executed anywhere on the hpc to load the fastqc tool

components.data: Run FastQC on all of your fastq files and store the output in the directory you made in the previous step.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Run FastQC on all of your fastq files and store the output in the directory you made in the previous step.

source_data.name: $ fastqc *.fastq -o /rsgrps/bh_class/username/quality_control
source_data.description:
Make sure to move into YOUR directory containing YOUR fastq files.

The -o command will put the output from fastqc into the directory specified.

components.data: Make a directory for FastQC output.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Make a directory for FastQC output.

source_data.name: $ mkdir /rsgrps/bh_class/username/quality_control
source_data.description: Make sure to replace username with the name of YOUR directory containing YOUR work.

components.data: Move into the quality_control directory that now contains the output of FastQC. Delete the .zip folders that were created (we only need the .html files).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Move into the quality_control directory that now contains the output of FastQC. Delete the .zip folders that were created (we only need the .html files).

source_data.name:
$ cd /rsgrps/bh_class/username/quality_control
$ rm -rf ./*.zip
source_data.description: CAUTION: rm -rf is a no going back command. Files removed are gone FOREVER. Make sure you are in the directory containing the FastQC files and execute as described above.

components.data: In order to view the html summary files you must "secure copy (scp)" to your local machine. Open a new terminal (don't log into hpc). Determine where you want to store the files on your local machine and move into that directory.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: In order to view the html summary files you must "secure copy (scp)" to your local machine. Open a new terminal (don't log into hpc). Determine where you want to store the files on your local machine and move into that directory.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 5 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation: Windows users using Cygwin, your file will be stored in C:/cygwin64/home/USER. Just open a new terminal window and proceed to next step.
source_data.thread_text: Windows users using Cygwin, your file will be stored in C:/cygwin64/home/USER. Just open a new terminal window and proceed to next step.
source_data.body: Windows users using Cygwin, your file will be stored in C:/cygwin64/home/USER. Just open a new terminal window and proceed to next step.

components.data: Execute the following command to scp the html files to your local machine:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Execute the following command to scp the html files to your local machine:

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 6 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation: Keep in mind that anytime FastQC is ran again and a new .html summary file is generated you must scp to your local machine in order to view it.
source_data.thread_text: Keep in mind that anytime FastQC is ran again and a new .html summary file is generated you must scp to your local machine in order to view it.
source_data.body: Keep in mind that anytime FastQC is ran again and a new .html summary file is generated you must scp to your local machine in order to view it.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 6 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation: At this step it asks me for the two-factor login again? Should I be getting this? It doesn't seem to have saved into my C:/cygwin/home/Emily folder on my computer either? (I have a PC)
source_data.thread_text: At this step it asks me for the two-factor login again? Should I be getting this? It doesn't seem to have saved into my C:/cygwin/home/Emily folder on my computer either? (I have a PC)
source_data.body: At this step it asks me for the two-factor login again? Should I be getting this? It doesn't seem to have saved into my C:/cygwin/home/Emily folder on my computer either? (I have a PC)

source_data.name: $ scp jamesthornton@login.hpc.arizona.edu:/rsgrps/bh_class/jetjr/quality_control/*.html .
source_data.description:
Replace jamesthornton with your own NETID. Also notice there is a period after *.html which indicates to put the files in the current directory. 

All files containing the .html extension will be copied to the current directory on the local machine.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 10 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation: See step 12 for an alternative method to obtain the .html files.
source_data.thread_text: See step 12 for an alternative method to obtain the .html files.
source_data.body: See step 12 for an alternative method to obtain the .html files.

components.data: Now you can view the FastQC results from the .html files.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Now you can view the FastQC results from the .html files.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 7 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation: Again, Windows users using Cygwin will have to go to C:/cygwin64/home/USER directory on your windows machine to find the file. In the windows 10 interface open file explorer, click "This PC", double click on Windows (C:), then cygwin64, then home, then USER. Your files should be there.
source_data.thread_text: Again, Windows users using Cygwin will have to go to C:/cygwin64/home/USER directory on your windows machine to find the file. In the windows 10 interface open file explorer, click "This PC", double click on Windows (C:), then cygwin64, then home, then USER. Your files should be there.
source_data.body: Again, Windows users using Cygwin will have to go to C:/cygwin64/home/USER directory on your windows machine to find the file. In the windows 10 interface open file explorer, click "This PC", double click on Windows (C:), then cygwin64, then home, then USER. Your files should be there.

source_data.name: $ open ./*.html
source_data.description:
Will open all .html files in the current directory into your default browser.

Remember this is on a local terminal (not connected to hpc). Double clicking on the files will work as well.

components.data: Determine the quality control steps and parameters needed to improve the quality of the reads by looking at the html summary for each sample. Keep in mind that each sample (file) will likely have different steps and parameters.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Determine the quality control steps and parameters needed to improve the quality of the reads by looking at the html summary for each sample. Keep in mind that each sample (file) will likely have different steps and parameters.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 13 of Sequence Quality Control
source_data.annotation:
We will review steps in class:

1. Clipping

2. Quality filtering

3. Read length filtering

4. Duplicate sequence removal

components.data: Load FastX Toolkit:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Load FastX Toolkit:

source_data.name: $ module load fastx
source_data.description: The FastX toolkit will allow us to take quality control steps on our sequences.

components.data:
Summary of tools available in the FastX toolkit can be viewed by the link given below.

 

Command line usage for these tools is here: http://hannonlab.cshl.edu/fastx_toolkit/commandline.html
components.name: Description

source_data.description:

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 11 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation: We are showing you a limited view into this total software package.  You can look here for more options.

components.data: The fastx_trimmer can be used if you see a decrease in quality at a specific base position:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The fastx_trimmer can be used if you see a decrease in quality at a specific base position:

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 12 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Preprocessing
source_data.annotation: It is possible that only some or even none of your samples will be trimmed. Look at the FastQC output to determine this.
source_data.thread_text: It is possible that only some or even none of your samples will be trimmed. Look at the FastQC output to determine this.
source_data.body: It is possible that only some or even none of your samples will be trimmed. Look at the FastQC output to determine this.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 13 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation: base pair quality usually decreases with length for most NGS technologies
source_data.thread_text: base pair quality usually decreases with length for most NGS technologies
source_data.body: base pair quality usually decreases with length for most NGS technologies

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 13 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation: fasqc can tell you where the drop in quality occurs for the sequences in a given file, reference the fastqc results to decide on the base pair position to trim from.
source_data.thread_text: fasqc can tell you where the drop in quality occurs for the sequences in a given file, reference the fastqc results to decide on the base pair position to trim from.
source_data.body: fasqc can tell you where the drop in quality occurs for the sequences in a given file, reference the fastqc results to decide on the base pair position to trim from.

source_data.name: $ fastx_trimmer -f 10 -l 200 -i [Infile] -o [outfile]
source_data.description:
where -f refers to the first base position and -l refers to the last

NOTE: this is just an example of how to use the trimmer. The actually parameters to run depends on your samples.

components.data: The fastq_quality_filter can be used to filter out reads that fail to reach a specific quality score:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The fastq_quality_filter can be used to filter out reads that fail to reach a specific quality score:

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 13 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Preprocessing
source_data.annotation: It's a good idea to run the quality filter on all of your samples, even if it the reads appear to have good quality already. The parameters used in the command on this step will work as a filter on your samples.
source_data.thread_text: It's a good idea to run the quality filter on all of your samples, even if it the reads appear to have good quality already. The parameters used in the command on this step will work as a filter on your samples.
source_data.body: It's a good idea to run the quality filter on all of your samples, even if it the reads appear to have good quality already. The parameters used in the command on this step will work as a filter on your samples.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 14 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation: Some reads are just bad, and have poor quality through out.  We want to remove these reads.  If these reads remain in the dataset, you will have issues down the line with assembly.  Garbage in = garbage out
source_data.thread_text: Some reads are just bad, and have poor quality through out.  We want to remove these reads.  If these reads remain in the dataset, you will have issues down the line with assembly.  Garbage in = garbage out
source_data.body: Some reads are just bad, and have poor quality through out.  We want to remove these reads.  If these reads remain in the dataset, you will have issues down the line with assembly.  Garbage in = garbage out

source_data.name: $ fastq_quality_filter -q 20 -p 80 -i [infile] -o [outfile]
source_data.description: -q refers to the minimum quality score to keep and -p is the minimum percent bases that must have -q quality

components.data: The fastx_clipper can remove reads below a certain minimum length. Remove reads that are less than 70 base pairs long by executing the following command:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The fastx_clipper can remove reads below a certain minimum length. Remove reads that are less than 70 base pairs long by executing the following command:

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 15 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation: After you trim your reads, some may be super short.  These reads are usually not long enough to contribute to down stream analyses such as assembly and taxonomic or functional annotation (we will go through these analysis steps later in the semester).
source_data.thread_text: After you trim your reads, some may be super short.  These reads are usually not long enough to contribute to down stream analyses such as assembly and taxonomic or functional annotation (we will go through these analysis steps later in the semester).
source_data.body: After you trim your reads, some may be super short.  These reads are usually not long enough to contribute to down stream analyses such as assembly and taxonomic or functional annotation (we will go through these analysis steps later in the semester).

source_data.name: $ fastx_clipper -l 70 -i [infile] -o [outfile]
source_data.description: -l sets the minimum length of reads. Fastx_clipper will remove any reads < 70

components.data: Finally, the fastx_collapser will collapse identical sequences into a single one. The collapser should always be last in the workflow because the output will be in Fasta format instead of Fastq.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Finally, the fastx_collapser will collapse identical sequences into a single one. The collapser should always be last in the workflow because the output will be in Fasta format instead of Fastq.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 16 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation: Here we are removing duplicates produced by the sequencing technology.  These data can bias your final results, so they need to be removed.
source_data.thread_text: Here we are removing duplicates produced by the sequencing technology.  These data can bias your final results, so they need to be removed.
source_data.body: Here we are removing duplicates produced by the sequencing technology.  These data can bias your final results, so they need to be removed.

source_data.name: $ fastx_collapser -i [infile] -o [outfile]
source_data.description: output will be in fasta format.

components.data: The next few steps will introduce some FastX tools and how they can be used one at a time on a file. It's possible to use multiple FastX tools at the same time and this is demonstrated in step 17.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The next few steps will introduce some FastX tools and how they can be used one at a time on a file. It's possible to use multiple FastX tools at the same time and this is demonstrated in step 17.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 16 of Sequence Quality Control
source_data.annotation: Woops, step 21 actually demonstrates multiple command option.
source_data.thread_text: Woops, step 21 actually demonstrates multiple command option.
source_data.body: Woops, step 21 actually demonstrates multiple command option.

components.data: You can also pipe together multiple commands:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: You can also pipe together multiple commands:

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 17 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation: Make files are also a great way to do this.  See Ken's gitbook and your homework assignment for how to do this.
source_data.thread_text: Make files are also a great way to do this.  See Ken's gitbook and your homework assignment for how to do this.
source_data.body: Make files are also a great way to do this.  See Ken's gitbook and your homework assignment for how to do this.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 17 of MG_HW3: Quality Control and Pre-processing
source_data.annotation:
You can also do this on the fly via a for loop.  Note that I put the names of my files in a file called "list"

% for file in `cat list`; do
> cat $file.fq | fastx_trimmer -f 12 -l 300 | fastq_quality_filter -q 20 -p 80 | fastx_clipper -l 60 | fastx_collapser > $file.fasta
> done
source_data.thread_text:
You can also do this on the fly via a for loop.  Note that I put the names of my files in a file called "list"

% for file in `cat list`; do
> cat $file.fq | fastx_trimmer -f 12 -l 300 | fastq_quality_filter -q 20 -p 80 | fastx_clipper -l 60 | fastx_collapser > $file.fasta
> done
source_data.body:
You can also do this on the fly via a for loop.  Note that I put the names of my files in a file called "list"

% for file in `cat list`; do
> cat $file.fq | fastx_trimmer -f 12 -l 300 | fastq_quality_filter -q 20 -p 80 | fastx_clipper -l 60 | fastx_collapser > $file.fasta
> done

source_data.name: cat SRR1647145_trimmed.fq |  fastx_trimmer -f 12 -l 175 | fastq_quality_filter -q 20 -p 80 | fastx_clipper -l 60 | fastx_collapser > SRR1647145.fasta
source_data.description: fastx_collapser should be last as the output will be in fasta format.

components.data: If your FASTQ files are still compressed (.gz extension), make sure to uncompress them.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: If your FASTQ files are still compressed (.gz extension), make sure to uncompress them.

source_data.name: $ gunzip *.gz
source_data.description: Remember, you must be in the directory containing your fastq files for this to work.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 4 of Sequence Quality Control
source_data.annotation:
what is the expected result when I gunzip?

 

it should return with no errors

 

Then you can ls-l and see that none of the files have .gz as an ext.

components.data:
Alternative method to obtain .html files. (Skip if scp was successful for you).

 

If you are having trouble using scp, you can "push" the .html files to your abe487 github repository. This will require you to copy them into your abe487 directory (used for computational homework). Then do a git add, git commit, git push.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Alternative method to obtain .html files. (Skip if scp was successful for you).

 

If you are having trouble using scp, you can "push" the .html files to your abe487 github repository. This will require you to copy them into your abe487 directory (used for computational homework). Then do a git add, git commit, git push.

source_data.name:
$ pwd
/rsgrps/bh_class/username/quality_control
$ mkdir ~/abe487/fastqc
$ cp *.html ~/abe487/fastqc
$ cd !$
$ git add *.html
$ git commit -m 'adding qc reports'
$ git push
source_data.description:
Make sure you are in the quality_control directory that contains your .html files.
Once complete, you can go to your github repository to download the report files for viewing.
